children.value: A vector is a mathematical quantity that has both
Geometrically, a vector is represented as a directed line segment, like an arrow, where the length signifies the magnitude and the arrowhead indicates the direction.
More conveniently, you may write a vector as

children.html: [12]\begin{bmatrix} 1 \\ 2 \end{bmatrix}[12​]
v⃗\vec{v}v

children.value: . Can you tell what the magnitude (or length or norm) of the above vector is?
Another way to represent a vector is by using basis vectors, i.e.

children.value: will not be zero, although the product will be a singular matrix.
Systems of Equations in Matrix Form

children.label: Systems of Equations in Matrix Form

children.value: One of the uses of linear algebra in economics is to represent and then solve systems of equations. For instance, consider the system of two equations:

children.html: 2x1+x2=5−x1+x2=22x_1 + x_2 = 5 \\ -x_1 + x_2 = 22x1​+x2​=5−x1​+x2​=2

A=[21−11],x=[x1x2],b=[52]\mathbf{A} = \begin{bmatrix} 2 & 1 \\ -1 & 1 \end{bmatrix}, \quad \mathbf{x} = \begin{bmatrix} x_1 \\ x_2 \end{bmatrix}, \quad \mathbf{b} = \begin{bmatrix} 5 \\ 2 \end{bmatrix}A=[2−1​11​],x=[x1​x2​​],b=[52​]

Ax=[21−11][x1x2]=[2x1+x2−x1+x2]\mathbf{A}\mathbf{x} = \begin{bmatrix} 2 & 1 \\ -1 & 1 \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} x_1 \\ x_2 \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} 2x_1 + x_2 \\ -x_1 + x_2 \end{bmatrix}Ax=[2−1​11​][x1​x2​​]=[2x1​+x2​−x1​+x2​​]

children.value: The original system is in fact equivalent to the matrix form:

children.html: Ax=b\mathbf{A}\mathbf{x} = \mathbf{b}Ax=b

children.value: Matrix row operations, also known as elementary row operations, are three basic actions performed on a matrix:
multiplying a row by a non-zero constant
adding a multiple of one row to another row
(Row Swapping): You can swap the positions of any two rows in a matrix. As we will see later, this operation is useful for changing the order of equations in a system without altering the solution.
Multiplying a row by a non-zero constant
(Scalar Multiplication): You can multiply every element in a specific row by any non-zero number. This is equivalent to multiplying both sides of an equation by a constant.
Adding a multiple of one row to another row

(Row Addition): You can multiply one row by a constant and then add the result to another row. The original row and the row being multiplied remain unchanged. This operation is often the most powerful for simplifying systems, as it corresponds to adding a modified version of one equation to another.
Every non-zero row begins with a leading one.
A leading one in a lower row is further to the right.
Zero rows are at the bottom of the matrix.
Note: In some books, leading by one is not required.
Every non-zero row begins with a leading one.
A leading one in a lower row is further to the right.
Zero rows are at the bottom of the matrix.
with a leading one has zeros elsewhere.
While there can exist several row echelon forms for a matrix, there is only one (a unique) reduced row echelon form.

children.html: A=[200030005],B=[70000000−4],A = \begin{bmatrix} 2 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 3 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 5 \end{bmatrix}, \quad B = \begin{bmatrix} 7 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & -4 \end{bmatrix},A=⎣⎡​200​030​005​⎦⎤​,B=⎣⎡​700​000​00−4​⎦⎤​,

C=[212030005],D=[700−20031−4].C = \begin{bmatrix} 2 & 1 & 2 \\ 0 & 3 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 5 \end{bmatrix}, \quad D = \begin{bmatrix} 7 & 0 & 0 \\ -2 & 0 & 0 \\ 3 & 1 & -4 \end{bmatrix}.C=⎣⎡​200​130​205​⎦⎤​,D=⎣⎡​7−23​001​00−4​⎦⎤​.

children.value: Basically, a matrix can be viewed as a way to transform or change a vector to solve these systems!
The system provides the unique solution:

children.html: x1=1,x2=3x_1 = 1, \quad x_2 = 3x1​=1,x2​=3

). At Step 4, the last row tells us that

x1−3=−2  ⟹  x1=1x_1 - 3 = -2 \implies x_1 = 1x1​−3=−2⟹x1​=1

The determinant is a scalar value uniquely associated with a square non-singular matrix, and is usually denoted as

children.html: ∣A∣|\mathbf{A}|∣A∣

children.value: . The question of whether or not a matrix is nonsingular and therefore invertible is linked to the value of its determinant.

children.html: −(−3)⋅∣123−1∣=3⋅[(1)(−1)−(2)(3)]=3(−1−6)=−21-(-3) \cdot \begin{vmatrix} 1 & 2 \\ 3 & -1 \end{vmatrix} = 3 \cdot [(1)(-1) - (2)(3)] = 3(-1 - 6) = -21−(−3)⋅∣∣​13​2−1​∣∣​=3⋅[(1)(−1)−(2)(3)]=3(−1−6)=−21

children.value: Interchanging any two rows or columns will affect the sign of the determinant, but not its absolute value.
Multiplying a single row or column by a scalar will cause the value of the determinant to be multiplied by the scalar.
Addition or subtraction of a nonzero multiple of any row or column to or from another row or column does not change the value of the determinant.
The determinant of a triangular matrix is equal to the product of the elements along the principal diagonal.
If any of the rows or columns equal zero, the determinant is also zero.
If two rows or columns are identical or proportional, i.e. linearly dependent, then the determinant is zero.
are standard row operations already discussed above.

children.value: Finding the Inverse of a Matrix (Standard Approach)

children.label: Finding the Inverse of a Matrix (Standard Approach)

children.value: The inverse of a matrix is defined as:

children.html: A−1=1∣A∣adj⁡(A)\mathbf{A}^{-1} = \frac{1}{|\mathbf{A}|} \operatorname{adj}(\mathbf{A})A−1=∣A∣1​adj(A)

children.value: Let’s say we have the following linear system:

children.html: 2x1−3x2+x3=−1x1−x2+2x3=−33x1+x2−x3=92x_1 - 3x_2 + x_3 = -1 \\ x_1 - x_2 + 2x_3 = -3 \\ 3x_1 + x_2 - x_3 = 92x1​−3x2​+x3​=−1x1​−x2​+2x3​=−33x1​+x2​−x3​=9

children.value: Writing the above system in the form

children.html: Ax=b\mathbf{A}\mathbf{x} = \mathbf{b}Ax=b

A=[2−311−1231−1],x=[x1x2x3],b=[−1−39]\mathbf{A} = \begin{bmatrix} 2 & -3 & 1 \\ 1 & -1 & 2 \\ 3 & 1 & -1 \end{bmatrix}, \quad \mathbf{x} = \begin{bmatrix} x_1 \\ x_2 \\ x_3 \end{bmatrix}, \quad \mathbf{b} = \begin{bmatrix} -1 \\ -3 \\ 9 \end{bmatrix}A=⎣⎡​213​−3−11​12−1​⎦⎤​,x=⎣⎡​x1​x2​x3​​⎦⎤​,b=⎣⎡​−1−39​⎦⎤​

children.value: We can therefore solve the system by

children.html: x=A−1b\mathbf{x} = \mathbf{A}^{-1}\mathbf{b}x=A−1b
